Description: Fiat S.p.A. and its subsidiary CNH Global N.V. settled allegations that from 2000 through 2003 certain of their subsidiaries made approximately $4.3 million in kickback payments in connection with the sale of humanitarian goods to Iraq under the United Nations Oil for Food Program.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/litigation/litreleases/2008/lr20835.htm

Description: Fiat S.p.A. agreed to a $7 million penalty for illegal kickbacks paid to officials of the former Iraqi government by three of its subsidiaries. Fiat agreed to pay the fine as part of a deferred prosecution agreement. The matter was part of the Justice Department's ongoing investigation into the United Nations Oil for Food program.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2008/December/08-crm-1140.html

Description: The Department of Justice, the EPA and the State of California announced a settlement with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles N.V., FCA US, and affiliates for alleged violations of the Clean Air Act and California law. Fiat Chrysler agreed to implement a recall program to repair more than 100,000 noncompliant diesel vehicles sold or leased in the United States, offer an extended warranty on repaired vehicles, and pay a civil penalty of $305 million to settle claims of cheating emission tests and failing to disclose unlawful defeat devices. Fiat Chrysler also agreed to implement a program to mitigate excess pollution from these vehicles.  The recall and federal mitigation programs were estimated to cost up to approximately $185 million. In a separate settlement with California, Fiat Chrysler agreed to pay an additional $19 million to mitigate excess emissions from more than 13,000 of the noncompliant vehicles in California. In addition, in a separate administrative agreement with the United States Customs and Border Protection, Fiat Chrysler agreed to  pay a $6 million civil penalty to resolve allegations of illegally importing 1,700 noncompliant vehicles.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/civil-settlements-united-states-and-california-fiat-chrysler-will-resolve-allegations

Description: Fiat Chrysler told reporters in February 2019 that it had paid $77 million for CAFE violations in 2016. The information was not made public by NHTSA.
Info Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-fiat-chrysler-emissions-penalties/fiat-chrysler-paid-77-million-in-u-s-fuel-economy-penalties-in-2018-idUSKCN1PW2PZ

Description: Fiat Chrysler and Robert Bosch agreed to pay a total of more than $170 million to settle multistate litigation alleging they illegally altered measurements of vehicle emissions when Fiat installed Bosch electronics designed to evade diesel emission tests. Fiat Chrysler's share was $72.5 million.
Info Source: http://illinoisattorneygeneral.gov/pressroom/2019_01/20190110b.html

Description: Michigan-based automaker FCA US LLC and its parent company Fiat Chrysler Automobiles N.V. agreed to pay $40 million to settle allegations that the company misled investors about the number of new vehicles sold each month to customers in the United States.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/news/press-release/2019-196

Description: DaimlerChrysler, now part of Fiat, agreed to settle a lawsuit alleging that it discriminated against African-American and Latino customers by charging them more for car loans. The company agreed to make hundreds of thousands of loans to minority customers on special terms, but no value was put on that part of the settlement. DaimlerChrysler also agreed to pay $65,000 to the class representatives, contribute $1.8 million to consumer education programs and pay $7.7 million in plaintiffs' legal fees and expenses.
Private Litigation Case Title: Smith, et al v. Chrysler Financial, et al
Info Source: https://www.autonews.com/article/20050726/REG/507260706/daimlerchrysler-settles-discrimination-lawsuit

Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/news/press-release/2020-230

Description: FCA, a subsidiary of Stellantis, agreed to pay $30 million after pleading guilty to charges of participating in a conspiracy to violate the Taft-Hartley Act by making more than $3.5 million in illegal payments to officers of the International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace, and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW) between 2009 and 2016.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-edmi/pr/fca-us-llc-sentenced-connection-conspiracy-make-illegal-payments-uaw-officials
